t: Ecclesiastes 1
The Futility of All Endeavor
The*p words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
“Vanity*pn of vanities,” says the Preacher, “Vanity*ln of vanities! All is vanity.”
What*ln advantage does man have in all his work Which*ln he does under the sun?
A*ln generation goes and a generation comes, But*ln the earth remains forever.
Also,*ln the sun rises and the sun sets; And*ln hastening to its place it rises there again.*i
Blowing*ln toward the south, Then*ln turning toward the north, The*ln wind continues swirling along; And*ln on its circular courses the wind returns.
All*ln the rivers flow into the sea, Yet*ln the sea is not full. To*ln the place where the rivers flow, There*ln they flow again.
All*ln things are wearisome; Man*ln is not able to tell it.*i The*ln eye is not satisfied with seeing, Nor*ln is the ear filled with hearing.
That*ln which has been is that which will be, And*ln that which has been done is that which will be done. So*ln there is nothing new under the sun.
Is*ln there anything of which one might say, “See*ln this, it is new”? Already*ln it has existed for ages Which*ln were before us.
There*ln is no remembrance of earlier things; And*ln also of the later things which will occur, There*ln will be for them no remembrance Among*ln those who will come later still.*i
The Futility of Wisdom
I,*p the Preacher, have been king over Israel in Jerusalem.
And I set my mind to seek and explore by wisdom concerning all that has been done under heaven. It*i is a grievous task which*i God has given to the sons of men to be afflicted with.
I have seen all the works which have been done under the sun, and behold, all is vanity and striving after wind.
What is crooked cannot be straightened and what is lacking cannot be counted.
I*p said to myself, “Behold, I have magnified and increased wisdom more than all who were over Jerusalem before me; and my mind has observed a wealth of wisdom and knowledge.”
And I set my mind to know wisdom and to know madness and folly; I realized that this also is striving after wind.
Because in much wisdom there is much grief, and increasing knowledge results*i in*i increasing pain.
